H0.text: According to the Bible, who was the high priest of Judea at the time of Christ's arrest and execution. Annas

H1.text: According to the Bible, who was the high priest of Judea at the time of Christ's arrest and execution. Caiaphas' predecessor

H2.text: According to the Bible, who was the high priest of Judea at the time of Christ's arrest and execution. Jonathan ben Ananus

H3.text: According to the Bible, who was the high priest of Judea at the time of Christ's arrest and execution. Caifa

A4.text: Joseph ben Caiaphas was the High Priest of Israel during the first century.

A5.text: He was made high priest by the Roman procurator Valerius Gratus after Simon ben Camithus had been deposed.

A6.text: Annas served officially as High Priest for ten years (AD 6–15)

A7.text: Shortly after he was announced High Priest of Israel, he was killed in AD 58 by Antonius Felix, the Roman procurator of the province Judea.

A8.text: Felix persuaded one of Jonathan's most trusted friends, Doras, a citizen of Jerusalem, to hire robbers to kill Jonathan by promising to give a large sum of money.

A9.text: However, the ossuary only refers to Theophilus as a high priest, so it may have been a different person.

A12.text: The Roman general Aulus Gabinius invaded Judea in retaliation, sent Hyrcanus back to Jerusalem, and reinstated him as high priest.

A13.text: Phasael committed suicide, and Hyrcanus II was taken as a prisoner to Babylon after having his ear severed in order to prevent him from ever acting as high priest again.

A14.text: Mark does not name the High Priest.
